												This is quite a good game, once you can get to grips with its quirks. However, it really pays to have some experience with flight simming (or even real piloting), because this game is NOT novice-friendly. Unlike Microsoft Flight Simulator X, which has tutorial missions and a wealth of information in its Learning Center (including detailed information about how to fly its default aircraft), X-Plane basically throws you in the cockpit and says "best of British" to you. There are no tutorials, at least not within the game. It doesn't work all that well "out of the box", either. You have to spend some time configuring it (especially with regard to your controller). This is good in some ways, because X-Plane offers a lot of options for customisation and is very flexible in this regard. But in other ways, it's a bit tedious, especially as the user interface is not very user-friendly. Granted, there are plenty of forums where you can get good information, but it would be nice to have more of the information you really need within the game itself.The scenery (minus any add-ons) is somewhat of a mixed bag. In terms of topography, X-Plane leaves FSX in the dust. The way in which hills, fields and so on are rendered is every bit as good as high-quality FSX scenery add-ons like Orbx or texture add-ons like REX. Water and lighting are also quite magnificent. Runways are (at least in my opinion) easier to see. Weather is very well done. However, where X-Plane trails a fair way behind FSX (and I think, Prepar3D) is in the way airports are depicted - often just bare runways and taxiways with no buildings at all. This is really very poor. Cities are not very well depicted either. While FSX default rendering of cities is pretty ordinary, it is still, at this time, vastly superior to X-Plane (again, I refer purely to default scenery - obviously, the scenery of both these flight sims can be improved with add-ons).Another area where X-Plane falls short of FSX is AI aircraft. While it is nice to see real airlines (like United) instead of the generic airlines you get in FSX, the type of aircraft are often wrong for the airport. For instance, at my home airport (which is a major international airport, but has a fairly short runway), I saw a United Airlines Boeing 747. United doesn't fly to my city, and the runway is too short for 747s. Even more absurdly, I saw a NASA 747! Another crazy sight I saw was a Hercules (or something similar) doing all manner of weird somersaults before eventually righting itself and rolling down the runway for takeoff. AI aircraft in FSX aren't perfect, but they never do that! And the aircraft type is usually correct for the airport you're at. So this is another area of X-Plane that really needs some work.As for your own aircraft, they have nice interiors and decent flight dynamics. More 2D pop-up panels would be helpful though (maybe add-ons provide these, but the default planes don't seem to, except for the Garmin GPS), and sometimes the instruments can be hard to read. Sure, you can zoom in on them, but then how are you supposed to see outside? Things like radios and the altimeter have be adjusted manually, but this is not too hard to do. Autopilots are a bit tricky. By the way, for looking around, I recommend using the mouse (zoom in and out with the scroll wheel, and hold down the right button to pan around). Much better than the keyboard. There's also your joystick's hat switch, but you have to manually configure this (X-Plane won't recognise your joystick the way FSX will), which is not that easy. By far and away the best way to look around, or zoom in and out, is with the mouse.One thing I enjoy doing a lot in FSX is IFR flights between one place and another. It's very straightforward to create a flight plan in FSX. generate a navigation log and interact with ATC. You can do IFR flights in X-Plane as well, but it's far less straightforward (though I'm sure there are add-ons to make it easier). In FSX, you can search for a depature point by airport name, ICAO code or city. Likewise for your destination. But when filing a flight plan in X-Plane, you can only enter the ICAO codes for your departure and arrival points. I guess it's not too hard to look these up somewhere, but this is an example of how X-Plane is not friendly to newbies. Then too, you have to enter a route comprising VORs, DMEs or whatever (although you can leave this section blank and just fly direct, which is best for short flights). But it's not entirely clear how you should do this, what format it should take etc. There's no navigation log, which I love in FSX and really miss in X-Plane. Another thing to beware of is that X-Plane won't park your aircraft at a departure point the way FSX does. You have to choose your airport and gate/ramp BEFORE setting up a flight plan, and you will be returned to that same spot once you're done with your flight plan.Interacting with ATC takes a bit of getting used to in X-Plane. Whereas FSX will automatically tune you to your departure airport's Clearance Delivery frequency to get you started, you have to manually find the frequency in X-Plane. Better realism, granted, but it can be rather disconcerting at first. Actually, there is a rather handy trick that can help you with ATC in X-Plane. Go to the "Special" menu and select Toggle ATC (that's not exactly what it's called, but anyway it's about halfway down the Special drop-down menu). This brings up a little yellow box that you can use to "auto-tune" frequencies (select the "recommended" one). When ATC says something to you, make sure that you acknowledge their transmission or they'll just keep repeating themselves ad nauseam. Another thing X-Plane's ATC will do is tell you you're off course when you've just taken off and are flying the runway heading to gain a safe altitude, but are (temporarily) going in the opposite direction to your destination. This is quite annoying and I hope it will be fixed. Note also that ATC won't tell you to change course after you've taken off. They expect you to know where you're going (a novel concept). But when you are getting closer to your arrival airport, they will give you altitude and heading instructions that more closely resemble what the FSX ATC does. And I actually think the vectoring of X-Plane's ATC may be a little more precise.If you are a complete and utter novice to flight simming, you would be better off starting with FSX or the upcoming Dovetail Games Flight School. Certainly in FSX, you can learn a LOT about the fundamentals of flying. X-Plane does not teach you these fundamentals and frankly throws you in the deep end. But if you DO understand the basics of flying (or indeed have reasonable experience with FSX and/or Prepar3D) and you can get the hang of X-Plane's interface (which is a learning curve in its own right), and if you can live with the weird AI aircraft behaviour and total lack of buildings at many airports, then X-Plane is well worth investing in, especially for its topography rendering, weather and aircraft flight dynamics. So I recommend it, albeit with a few caveats.
